children.name: man of means
children.definition: man/woman/person of means/ˌmæn, ˌwʊmən, ˌpɜːʳsən əv ˈmiːnz/  a person who is very rich, usually because they own land, property etc or because they have a family that has always been rich:

children.name: người có của ăn của để, người giàu
examples: ▪ Taylor is a man of means. His family owns several apartment blocks in New York.
▪ These were people of means who could afford to pay expensive legal fees.

children.name: millionaire
children.definition: /ˌmɪljəˈneəʳ/  a person who has a million pounds or dollars, or more:
examples: triệu phí
▪ The money to keep the hospital open was provided by a London millionaire.
▪ I can’t afford a new car just now. I’m no millionaire, you know.
millionairenoun[ C ]
(female alsomillionairess)nhà triệu phú;người giàu bạc triệu
a person who has at least 1 000 000 in their country's money
_You want me to buy you a new car - do you think I'm a millionaire or something?

children.name: multi-millionaire
children.definition: /ˌmʌlti mɪljəˈneəʳ/  a person who has many millions of pounds or dollars:
examples: ▪ Louis Berg is a multi-millionaire who made his money in the newspaper business.
multimillionairenoun[ C ] nhà triệu triệu phú
a person who has money and property worth several million pounds or dollars

children.name: magnate
children.definition: /ˈmægneɪt, -nt/  a rich and powerful person in a particular industry:
examples: ông trùm , ông vua...
▪ Foundations set up by magnates such as Carnegie and Rockefeller provided most of the funding for the arts in the US.
steel/oil/shipping etc magnate
▪ She married a Texan oil magnate.▪ the property magnate who owns the Empire State Building

children.name: fat cat
children.definition: /ˌfæt ˈkæt/  someone who makes a lot of money from a particular industry or business - use this about people who you think donot deserveto earn so much because they do not run their industry well, do not provide a good service etc:

children.name: nhà tài phiệt, nhà tư bản kếch xù
examples: ▪ They do not resent the city fat cats, but believe top businessmen deserve success.
▪ Why should those fat cats get rich through our efforts?

children.name: moneybags
children.definition: /ˈmʌnibægz/  informal use this when you are saying in ahumorousway that someone has a lot of money:

children.name: kẻ trọc phú
examples: ▪ Nowadays, if you’re not a moneybags, some places don’t want to have anything to do with you.

children.name: the rich
children.definition: /ðə ˈrɪtʃ/  all the people who are richin a particularcountry, society etc - use this especially when you arecomparingthem with people who are poor:
examples: ▪ Under this government the rich seem to have got richer and the poor poorer.
▪ Democracy gave the poor, as well as the rich, a part to play in governing the city.
the rich and famous
▪ a tour around the Hollywood homes of the rich and famous
the rich người giàu có
rich people considered together as a group
_The resort is frequented by the rich and famous.

children.name: the wealthy
children.definition: /ðə ˈwelθi/  people who are rich, especially through owning land, property, or valuable possessions over a long period of time, who have a lot of power or influence in society:
examples: ▪ Private health care should not be only for the wealthy.
▪ The hotel stood by a lake, where the wealthy went to go fishing or pigeon shooting.
the wealthy người giàu có
rich people

children.name: the haves and the have nots
children.definition: the haves and have-nots

children.name: the people who are not poor and the people who are poor
examples: _The government's change of policy is intended to reduce the gap between the haves and have-nots in our society.

children.name: billionaire
children.definition: noun tỉ phú
examples: a person whosewealthis at least 1 000 000 000 in their country's money

children.name: get rich
children.definition: /ˌget ˈrɪtʃ/
examples: ▪ I’m trying to think of a way to get rich.

children.name: get rich (by) doing something
examples: ▪ Mr Askin got rich selling second hand cars.

children.name: get rich quick
examples: ▪ The company promised its sales team that, if they worked hard enough, they would get rich quick.

children.name: make a fortune
children.definition: /bundle also make a bomb British /ˌmeɪk ə ˈfɔːʳtʃən, ˈbʌndl, ˌmeɪk ə ˈbɒmǁ-ˈbɑːm/ informalto become very rich by earning or winning a lot of money:

children.name: kiếm được cả gia tài
examples: ▪ If you’re a good salesman you can make a bomb, but you have to work hard.
▪ You shouldn’t have sold your shares. You could have made a bundle.

children.name: make a fortune etc (by) doing something
examples: ▪ Richard made a fortune breeding racehorses.

children.name: make good
children.definition: /ˌmeɪk ˈgʊd/to become rich, especially when you are from a poor family - used especially innewspapers:

children.name: trở nên giàu có
examples: ▪ He’s just a poor country boy who made good in the city.
▪ Ian thinks that just because he made good, everybody else can too.

children.name: marry into money
children.definition: /ˈmæri ɪntə ˌmʌni/  to become rich by marrying a rich person:
examples: ▪ If you don’t have any yourself, it’s a pretty smart move to marry into money!

children.name: from rags to riches
children.definition: go /gəʊ frəm ˌrægz tə ˈrɪtʃz/  to become very rich after being extremely poor:
examples: từ nghèo đói trở nên giàu có, phất lên
▪ Although he came from a poor family, he managed to go from rags to riches.
rags-to-riches[adjective phrase]
▪ a classic rags-to-riches story

children.name: be made/set up for life
children.definition: /biː ˌmeɪd, set ˌʌp fəʳ ˈlaɪf/  if you say that someone is made for life or is set up for life, you mean they are extremely successful and so rich that they do not need to work any more:
examples: ▪ Now he’s got a contract to advertise sports clothing he’ll be made for life.
▪ Sylvester Stallone need never make another movie. He’s already set up for life.

children.name: having a lot of money or possessions
rich
children.definition: /rɪtʃ/
examples: ▪ Her new boyfriend is very good-looking and very rich.
▪ You have to be rich to afford anything in this shop.
▪ The rich countries of the world have promised more aid for developing countries.
▪ Every year ‘Fortune’ magazine publishes a list of the 100 richest people in America.
richadjectiveMONEYgiàu, giàu có
having a lot of money or valuable possessions
_He's the third richest man inBritain.
_They're one of the world's richest nations.
_He is determined togetrich quickly.

children.name: wealthy
children.definition: /ˈwelθi/  rich, especially through owning land, property, or valuable possessions over alongperiod of time:
examples: giàu sang
▪ She comes from a wealthy family, who own houses in London and Paris.
▪ The new taxes were aimed at the largest and wealthiest corporations.
▪ You would never have guessed from meeting him how immensely wealthy he was.
wealth[uncountable noun]
▪ The discovery of oil brought great wealth to the area made the people there very wealthy.
▪ a country where there are extremes of wealth and poverty
wealthyadjectivegiàu sang; giàu có
rich
_He's a very wealthy man.
_With their natural resources they are potentially a very wealthy country.

children.name: well off
children.definition: /ˌwel ˈɒf◂/  having more money than most people, so that you have a comfortable and easy life:
examples: khá giả
▪ They were sufficiently well off to buy their own apartment.
relatively/reasonably well off
▪ a relatively well off family
better off
▪ The government claim that people are better off now than they have ever been.
well-off,well offadjectiveRICHthịnh vượng; giàu có; khágiả
rich
_Her family was very well-off.

children.name: well-to-do
children.definition: /ˌwel tə ˈduː◂/  rich and respected because you have a fairlyhighposition in society:
examples: thịnh vượng, khá giả
well-to-do family/background
▪ He wants to find a husband from a well-to-do background for his daughter.
▪ Surprisingly, police statistics show that many of these thefts were carried out by people from well-to-do families.
well-to-do area/neighbourhood
▪ Educational facilities are best in the more well-to-do residential areas.

children.name: affluent
children.definition: /ˈæfluənt/  having a lot of money, especially as a result of your own hard work - use this when talking about people in aparticular countryorgroupin society:
examples: giàu
▪ As people become more affluent, so their standard and style of living improves.
affluent suburb : vùng ngoại ô giàu có
▪ We drove through affluent suburbs with large houses and tree-lined streets.
affluent society
▪ Consumer goods are a symbol of prestige in an affluent society.
affluence[uncountable noun]
▪ Since the Second World War there has been an increasing level of affluence in the West.
affluentadjective giàu có; thịnh vượng
having a lot of money or owning a lot of things; rich
_affluent nations/neighbourhoods

children.name: prosperous
children.definition: /ˈprɒspərəsǁˈprɑː-/  having a lot of money and a high standard of living, especially as a result of being successful inbusiness:
examples: phát đạt
▪ a prosperous American businessman
▪ After the war, Germany became one of Europe’s most prosperous countries.
prosperity/prɒˈsperɪti, prɒˈsperətiǁprɑː-/ [uncountable noun]
▪ The town’s prosperity comes from the textile industry.
prosperousadjectivethịnh vượng, phát đạt, phồn vinh, thành công
successful, usually by earning a lot of money
_In a prosperous country like this, no one should go hungry.

children.name: comfortably off
children.definition: be /biː ˌkʌmftəbli ˈɒfǁ-ˌkʌmfərt-/  to have enough money to live comfortably without worrying about money:

children.name: sung túc
examples: ▪ When the children were small we never had much money, but now we seem to be comfortably off.

children.name: comfortable
children.definition: /ˈkʌmftəbəl, ˈkʌmfət-ǁˈkʌmfərt-, ˈkʌmft-/  having enough money to live comfortably without worrying about money - use this about people or their financial situation:
examples: sung túc
▪ My wife and I are very lucky, really, we’re comfortable, even though we’re both retired.
have a comfortable life
▪ They’ve had a much more comfortable life since she started her new job.
in comfortable circumstances : hoàn cảnh sung túc
▪ He had supposed Mrs Mack to have been in comfortable circumstances, so he was surprised when he saw her tiny apartment.
comfortableadjectiveENOUGH MONEYsung túc
having enough money for a good standard of living
_They're not fabulously rich or anything, but they're quite comfortable.

children.name: be worth a fortune
children.definition: /be worth millions/biː ˌwɜːʳθ ə ˈfɔːʳtʃən, biː ˌwɜːʳθ ˈmɪljənz/  to be extremely rich, especially because you have earned a lot of money inbusiness, or throughsport,entertainmentetc:
examples: ▪ Michael Jackson must be worth a fortune.
▪ The Chief Executive started her career as a secretary, and now she’s worth millions.

children.name: be loaded
children.definition: /be rolling in it/biː ˈləʊdd, biː ˈrəʊlɪŋ ɪn ɪt/ informalto be extremely rich:

children.name: rất giàu
examples: ▪ Did you know Peter has three houses? He must be loaded.
▪ Some of her friends are absolutely rolling in it.

children.name: stinking /filthy rich
children.definition: stinking/filthy rich/ˌstɪŋkɪŋ, ˌfɪlθi ˈrɪtʃ/ spokeninformalextremely rich - use this especially when you think this isunfair:

children.name: rất giàu
examples: ▪ Gregory is filthy rich but he never gives a penny to charity.
▪ This gorgeous woman walked in, beautifully dressed and obviously stinking rich.

children.name: have money to burn
children.definition: /hæv ˌmʌni tə ˈbɜːʳn/to have so much money that you can buy anything you want, even things that you do not need:
examples: ▪ Every time I see her she’s wearing something new. She must have money to burn.
▪ Unless you’ve got money to burn, these expensive guitars are not the instruments to get you started.

children.name: having a lot of money now, but not always rich
flush
children.definition: /flʌʃ/  informal:

children.name: nhiều tiền
examples: ▪ I’ll buy the drinks, I’m feeling flush just now.

children.name: ▪ Alan gives his wife fifty dollars a week, or a little more if he’s flush
be in the money
children.definition: /biː ɪn ðə ˈmʌni/  informal to have a lot of money now because you have received some money unexpectedly, for example by winning a prize:

children.name: có được đống tiền ( trúng số ... )
examples: ▪ He used to be always wanting a loan, and then all at once, he was in the money.

children.name: ways of telling sb that you are not rich
I’m not made of money
children.definition: /aɪm ˌnɒt ˈmeɪd əv ˌmʌni/ say this when someone wants you to spend more money than you think you can afford:
examples: ▪ ‘Why don’t you move to a bigger house?’ ‘I’m not made of money, you know!’

children.name: money doesn’t grow on trees
children.definition: /ˌmʌni dʌzənt ˌgrəʊ ɒn ˈtriːz/ say this when someone, such as your child, husband, or wife, is spending more of your money than you think you can afford:
examples: ▪ Look how much you’ve spent on clothes this month! Money doesn’t grow on trees, you know!

children.name: wealth
children.definition: nounMONEYsự giàu có; sự giàu sang

children.name: prosperity
children.definition: nounsự thịnh vượng; sự phát đạt; sự phồn vinh

children.name: the state of being successful and having a lot of money
examples: _A country's future prosperity depends, to an extent, upon the quality of education of its people.
_The war was followed by a long period of peace and prosperity.

children.name: comfort
children.definition: noun

children.name: self-made
children.definition: adjective đủ sống; tự trang trải
examples: rich and successful as a result of your own work and not because of family money
_a self-made man/millionaire
